Title: How prove this inequality $2a^ab^bc^cd^d\ge ac+bd$
Content:
Let $a,b,c,d$ be positive numbers such that $a+b+c+d=2$. Show that
$$2a^ab^bc^cd^d\ge ac+bd$$
My try: I think maybe I can use this inequality
$$(1+x)^n\ge 1+nx \hspace{12pt} (n>1)$$
then I can't get it to work. I think this inequality may be solved by nice methods. Thank you.
AcceptedAnswer:
If $a \neq c$, then look at what happens if we replace both $a$ and $c$ with $x = (a+c)/2$ : $x^2 \ge x^2 - (\frac {a-c}2)^2 = ac$. Since the function $x \mapsto x \log x$ is convex (its second derivative is $1/x$ which is positive),
$\log(a^ac^c) = a \log a + c \log c \ge 2x \log x = \log (x^{2x})$. Hence $2a^ab^bc^cd^d \ge 2x^xb^bx^xd^d$ , $x^2+bd \ge ac+bd$ , and we still have $x+b+x+d = a+b+c+d = 2$ so it is enough to prove the inequality when $a=c$ (and when $b=d$, for symmetry reasons). So we are left with proving that if $x+y = 1$ then $2x^{2x}y^{2y} \ge x^2 + y^2$. Let $x = \frac {1+z}2$ and $y = \frac {1-z}2$. After simplifying, we have to prove that for $|z| < 1$, $(\frac{1+z}{1-z})^z \frac {1 - z^2}{1 + z^2} \ge 1$. Taking logs, we have to show $z \log(1+z) - z \log(1-z) + \log(1-z^2) - \log(1+z^2) \ge 0$.
Using $\log$'s power series at $1$, this is $(2z^2 + 2z^4/3 + 2z^6/5 + 2z^8/7 + 2z^{10}/9 +\ldots) - (2z^2 + 2z^6/3 + 2z^{10}/5 + \ldots) \ge
(2z^2 + 2z^6/3 + 2z^{10}/5 + 2z^{14}/7 + 2z^{18}/9 + \dots) - (2z^2 + 2z^6/3 + 2z^{10}/5 + \ldots) = 0$ There probably is something smarter to do instead, but this works.
